title: CPU Architecture üß†
ques: Explain the **fetch-decode-execute cycle** of a CPU.

answer.content:
**CPU Cycle:**

| Stage | Action |
|-------|--------|
| **Fetch** | Get instruction from memory (PC ‚Üí MAR ‚Üí Memory ‚Üí MBR) |
| **Decode** | Interpret instruction (Control Unit) |
| **Execute** | Perform operation (ALU for math/logic) |
| **Store** | Write result if needed |

**Key Registers:**
- PC (Program Counter): Next instruction address
- IR (Instruction Register): Current instruction
- ACC (Accumulator): Working value

explanation: Modern CPUs pipeline stages for parallel execution. Branch prediction and speculative execution increase performance.

title: Memory Hierarchy üìä
ques: Describe the **memory hierarchy** from fastest to slowest.

answer.content:
**Memory Hierarchy:**

| Level | Type | Speed | Size | Cost/byte |
|-------|------|-------|------|----------|
| 1 | Registers | ~1 ns | Bytes | $$$$$ |
| 2 | L1 Cache | ~1-4 ns | KB | $$$$ |
| 3 | L2/L3 Cache | ~10-40 ns | MB | $$$ |
| 4 | RAM | ~100 ns | GB | $$ |
| 5 | SSD | ~100 ¬µs | TB | $ |
| 6 | HDD | ~10 ms | TB | ¬¢ |

**Principle:** Locality of reference makes caching effective

explanation: CPU-memory speed gap is major bottleneck. Cache hit rates >95% for well-written programs.

title: Storage Types üíæ
ques: Compare **HDD, SSD, and NVMe** storage technologies.

answer.content:
| Feature | HDD | SATA SSD | NVMe SSD |
|---------|-----|----------|----------|
| **Technology** | Spinning platters | Flash memory | Flash memory |
| **Interface** | SATA | SATA | PCIe |
| **Read speed** | ~100 MB/s | ~500 MB/s | ~3500 MB/s |
| **Latency** | ~10 ms | ~0.1 ms | ~0.02 ms |
| **Durability** | Moving parts | No moving parts | No moving parts |
| **Cost/GB** | $ | $$ | $$$ |

explanation: SSDs have limited write cycles (TBW). NVMe eliminates SATA bottleneck for flash speeds.

title: Operating System Functions üñ•Ô∏è
ques: What are the main **functions of an operating system**?

answer.content:
**OS Functions:**

| Function | Description |
|----------|------------|
| **Process Management** | Scheduling, multitasking |
| **Memory Management** | Allocation, virtual memory |
| **File System** | Storage organization |
| **I/O Management** | Device drivers |
| **Security** | User authentication, permissions |
| **Networking** | Protocol stack, sockets |

**Types:**
- Batch, Time-sharing, Real-time
- Examples: Windows, Linux, macOS, Android

explanation: OS provides abstraction between hardware and applications. Kernel runs in privileged mode.

title: Network Layers üåê
ques: Explain the **OSI model** layers and their functions.

answer.content:
**OSI 7-Layer Model:**

| Layer | Name | Function | Example |
|-------|------|----------|--------|
| 7 | Application | User interface | HTTP, DNS |
| 6 | Presentation | Data format | SSL, JPEG |
| 5 | Session | Connection mgmt | RPC |
| 4 | Transport | End-to-end | TCP, UDP |
| 3 | Network | Routing | IP |
| 2 | Data Link | Frame delivery | Ethernet |
| 1 | Physical | Bits on wire | Cables |

*Mnemonic: Please Do Not Throw Sausage Pizza Away*

explanation: TCP/IP model has 4 layers. Understanding layers helps debug network issues.

title: Parallel Processing üîÑ
ques: Explain **multi-core processors** and the challenges of parallel programming.

answer.content:
**Multi-Core:**
- Multiple CPU cores on one chip
- Each core executes independently
- Shared cache and memory

**Parallel Programming Challenges:**
| Challenge | Description |
|-----------|------------|
| **Race conditions** | Unpredictable results from shared data |
| **Deadlock** | Processes waiting on each other |
| **Synchronization** | Coordinating access to shared resources |
| **Amdahl's Law** | Sequential portions limit speedup |

**Solutions:** Locks, semaphores, message passing

explanation: Moore's Law slowed; parallel is the path forward. GPU has 1000s of cores for parallel workloads.

title: Virtualization üñ•Ô∏èüñ•Ô∏è
ques: What is **virtualization** and how do VMs work?

answer.content:
**Virtualization:**
Running multiple virtual computers on one physical machine

**Components:**
- **Hypervisor:** Manages VMs
  - Type 1 (bare metal): VMware ESXi
  - Type 2 (hosted): VirtualBox
- **Guest OS:** OS running in VM
- **Virtual hardware:** CPU, memory, disk, network

**Benefits:**
- Server consolidation
- Isolation and security
- Easy backup/migration
- Development and testing

explanation: Containers (Docker) are lightweight alternative. Cloud computing relies heavily on virtualization.

title: Input/Output Devices üñ±Ô∏è
ques: How do **I/O devices** communicate with the CPU?

answer.content:
**I/O Communication Methods:**

| Method | Description | Use Case |
|--------|-------------|----------|
| **Polling** | CPU repeatedly checks device | Simple devices |
| **Interrupts** | Device signals CPU when ready | Keyboard, mouse |
| **DMA** | Device accesses memory directly | Disk, network |

**I/O Buses:**
- USB (Universal Serial Bus)
- PCIe (high-speed internal)
- SATA (storage)
- Thunderbolt (high-speed external)

**Device Drivers:** Software translating OS commands to device-specific instructions

explanation: DMA offloads data transfer from CPU. Interrupt handlers run when device needs attention.
